case_name: Narayanan and Viswanathan v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Chockalingam Chettiar and his son, Annamalai, were members of a Hindu joint family.

anchor.surface_text: Chockalingam Chettiar and his son, Annamalai, were members of a Hindu joint family.

facts.text: On March 28, 1939, the joint family status was severed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 28, 1939, the joint family status was severed.

facts.text: On February 2, 1943, Chockalingam executed a will devising the property which fell to his share.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1943, Chockalingam executed a will devising the property which fell to his share, in favour of his two grandsons - Narayanan and Viswanathan - and of the other grandsons that maybe born of his son, Annamalai.

facts.text: The will devised the property in favour of grandsons Narayanan and Viswanathan and other grandsons that may be born of son Annamalai.

anchor.surface_text: in favour of his two grandsons - Narayanan and Viswanathan - and of the other grandsons that maybe born of his son, Annamalai.

facts.text: The will provides that minor sons Narayanan and Viswanathan and male children born hereafter to Annamalai shall take and enjoy in equal shares all assets and liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the will were these After my lifetime, the minor sons of my divided son the aforesaid Annamalai Chettiar, viz., Narayanan and Viswanathan and the male children that may be born hereafter to the aforesaid Annamalai Chettiar shall take and enjoy in equal shares and with absolute rights all assets and liabilities in respect of immovable and movable properties

facts.text: The will appoints Annamalai Chettiar and his wife Meenakshi Achi as executors.

anchor.surface_text: I hereby appoint my divided son S.N.A.S. Annamalai Chettiar and his wife Meenakshi Achi as executors.

facts.text: Executors shall manage properties until the minors attain majority and then deliver to them.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, they shall after my lifetime manage and augment all my immovable and movable properties and firms, which are mentioned above, in their capacity as guardians and executors of the aforesaid minors, and when the aforesaid minors attain majority deliver the same to them.

facts.text: Chockalingam died on February 7, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Chockalingam on February 7, 1943, Meenakshi gave birth to two sons - Chockalingam on August 11, 1946, and Ramaswami on March 23, 1948.

facts.text: Meenakshi gave birth to son Chockalingam on August 11, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Meenakshi gave birth to two sons - Chockalingam on August 11, 1946, and Ramaswami on March 23, 1948.

facts.text: Meenakshi gave birth to son Ramaswami on March 23, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and Ramaswami on March 23, 1948.

facts.text: In assessment year 1951-52, Income-tax Officer assessed income of property on Narayanan and Viswanathan each entitled to moiety.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year 1951-52 the Income-tax Officer assessed the income of the property devised under the will of Chockalingam Chettiar on the footing that Narayanan and Viswanathan who were in existence at the time of his death were each entitled to a moiety of the estate.

facts.text: Similar assessments made for years 1952-53, 1953-54, 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: Similar orders of assessment were made for the year 1952-53, 1953-54 and 1956-57.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the orders of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the orders of the Income-tax Officer, and appeals to the Income-tax Tribunal failed.

facts.text: Appeals to Income-tax Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: and appeals to the Income-tax Tribunal failed.

facts.text: Income-tax Tribunal referred question to High Court of Judicature at Madras under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal referred to the High Court of Judicature at Madras the following question under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: Question referred: Whether the assessment on Viswanathan and Narayanan on a half share of the income of the estate is valid on proper construction of the will dated 2nd February, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessment on Viswanathan and Narayanan on a half share of the income of the estate of S.N.A.S. Chockalingam Chettiar is valid on a proper construction of the will dated 2nd February, 194 ?

facts.text: High Court answered the question affirmatively.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded an affirmative answer.

facts.text: High Court held that date of ascertainment of the class is date of testator's death per section 111 Indian Succession Act.

anchor.surface_text: They observed We are clearly of opinion that though the testator made a bequest to his grand-children by Annamalai and that such a bequest was to a class of heirs, there being no provision in the will, express or implied, indicating a period of distribution later than the death of the testator and there being no deferring of possession beyond the death, the date of ascertainment of the class must in view of section 111 of the Indian Succession Act be taken to be the date when the testator died.

facts.text: With special leave, Narayanan and Viswanathan appealed to this court.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, Narayanan and Viswanathan have appealed to this court.

facts.text: At date of testator's death, only two grandsons Narayanan and Viswanathan were alive.

anchor.surface_text: At the date of the testators death there were only two grandsons alive.

facts.text: Two more grandsons born after testator's death.

anchor.surface_text: Two more were born to Meenakshi - testators daughter-in-law after the death of the testator.

facts.text: Appellants contend that property devolves upon the four grandsons.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the property devolves upon the four grandsons of the testator, and the order of assessment levying tax from two of them only who were alive at the testators death is not valid.

facts.text: Court holds that possession of the class was not deferred beyond death of testator.

anchor.surface_text: But on the plain terms of the will possession of the class to whom the legacy was given was not deferred until a time later than the death of the testator.

facts.text: Appointment of guardians does not defer possession.

anchor.surface_text: Appointment of the parents of the grandsons as their guardians to manage the property for and on behalf of the minors had not the effect of deferring possession.

facts.text: No prior bequest or vesting in others; no postponement of vesting.

anchor.surface_text: The property was expressly given to the grandsons and such other grandsons that may be born. There was no prior bequest in favour of any other person, and legal possession of the property on the death of the testator was not vested in or reserved for any other person.

facts.text: Testator died within five days after execution of will.

anchor.surface_text: to the fact that the testator died within five days after the date of execution of the will.

facts.text: Court holds estate belonged only to Narayanan and Viswanathan.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that the estate belonged only to the two grandsons of the testators Narayanan and Viswanathan-and that they were properly assessed to tax in respect of the income therefrom.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act Whether the assessment on Viswanathan and Narayanan on a half share

issues.text: Whether the assessment on Viswanathan and Narayanan on a half share of the income of the estate of S.N.A.S. Chockalingam Chettiar is valid on a proper construction of the will dated 2nd February, 194?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessment on Viswanathan and Narayanan on a half share of the income of the estate of S.N.A.S. Chockalingam Chettiar is valid on a proper construction of the will dated 2nd February, 194 ?

issues.text: whether possession of the legatees to whom the legacy is bequeathed is deferred until a time later than the death of the testator

anchor.surface_text: the sole question which falls to be determined is whether possession of the legatees to whom the legacy is bequeathed is deferred until a time later than the death of the testator.

issues.text: Whether the class of grandsons entitled under the will includes those born after the testator's death

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily the will of a testator speaks on the date of his death. If a bequest is made to class of persons, then the thing bequeathed by the operation of section 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, goes only to persons belonging to that class as are alive at the testators death.

arguments.claim: Ordinarily the will of a testator speaks on the date of his death.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily the will of a testator speaks on the date of his death.

arguments.claim: Bequest to class of persons goes only to those alive at testator's death by operation of section 111 Indian Succession Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: If a bequest is made to class of persons, then the thing bequeathed by the operation of section 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, goes only to persons belonging to that class as are alive at the testators death.

arguments.claim: Exception to section 111: if possession deferred beyond death due to prior bequest or otherwise, class includes those alive at deferred date.

arguments.claim: High Court right: estate belonged only to Narayanan and Viswanathan; properly assessed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that the estate belonged only to the two grandsons of the testators Narayanan and Viswanathan-and that they were properly assessed to tax in respect of the income therefrom.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the estate belonged only to the two grandsons of the testator Narayanan and Viswanathan and that they were properly assessed to tax in respect of the income therefrom.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that the estate belonged only to the two grandsons of the testators Narayanan and Viswanathan-and that they were properly assessed to tax in respect of the income therefrom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 111 Indian Succession Act applies as no deferral of possession beyond testator's death; plain terms of will grant absolute rights after lifetime; guardians manage but do not defer possession; no prior bequest.

holdings.text: On the plain terms of the will possession of the class to whom the legacy was given was not deferred until a time later than the death of the testator.

anchor.surface_text: But on the plain terms of the will possession of the class to whom the legacy was given was not deferred until a time later than the death of the testator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will devises property to grandsons with absolute rights after testator's lifetime; no express deferral; management by guardians until majority does not constitute deferral of possession.

holdings.text: Appointment of the parents of the grandsons as their guardians to manage the property for and on behalf of the minors had not the effect of deferring possession.

anchor.surface_text: Appointment of the parents of the grandsons as their guardians to manage the property for and on behalf of the minors had not the effect of deferring possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guardians appointed to manage and deliver upon majority, but property expressly given absolutely after testator's death; management does not defer legal possession or vesting.

holdings.text: The property was expressly given to the grandsons and such other grandsons that may be born. There was no prior bequest in favour of any other person, and legal possession of the property on the death of the testator was not vested in or reserved for any other person. There was, therefore, no postponement of vesting of legal possession in the grandsons in existence at the date of the testator's death.

anchor.surface_text: The property was expressly given to the grandsons and such other grandsons that may be born. There was no prior bequest in favour of any other person, and legal possession of the property on the death of the testator was not vested in or reserved for any other person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct bequest to class of grandsons without intermediate vesting or prior interest; exception to section 111 does not apply absent deferral due to prior bequest or otherwise.

holdings.text: If a bequest is made to a class of persons, then the thing bequeathed by the operation of section 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, goes only to persons belonging to that class as are alive at the testator's death.

anchor.surface_text: If a bequest is made to class of persons, then the thing bequeathed by the operation of section 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, goes only to persons belonging to that class as are alive at the testators death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary rule under section 111; exception inapplicable here as possession not deferred.

holdings.text: There is no ambiguity in the terms of the will... it is not open to the court to speculate whether the testator could have contemplated the birth of any male children who may be born after the date of the execution of the will.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no ambiguity in the terms of the will. The will gives the estate to the grandsons who were in existence and the other male children who may be born after the date of the execution of the will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unambiguous language governs; cannot infer intention from extraneous circumstances like testator's health or short interval to death.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals by Narayanan and Viswanathan dismissed; High Court order upheld that only they two were liable for tax on the estate income.
